item.title: Comment on Crime vs. disorder by Mark
item.description:
Thinking about it economically, crime stats understate the magnitude of the problem because people adjust their behavior in response to higher crime, bringing crime back down, but not in a way that ‘solves the problem.’ Getting crime back down to where it was 10 years ago via no one leaving their house after 8pm and everyone avoiding 70% of their city like the plague isn’t really a good solution. Maybe a bit hyperbolic, but the goal is to have low crime by making cities safe, not by everyone adopting avoidant behavior. People doing victory laps over declining homicide numbers often fail to see the distinction between the two.

item.title: Comment on Crime vs. disorder by Phil S.
item.description:
A little over a month ago, my son's parked car was hit and run at high speed (body shop estimate ~50 mph) on a Saturday night. His car totalled. Debris from his car AND the car that hit him strewn over the street, including parts that could identify make and model (and maybe year and paint color) of car that hit him.

Police didn't even come in person to take report or look at any evidence - just a phone report.

Did that go in the city's crime reports? I'm skeptical...

Did it change my son's perception of living in the city? Darn tootin'
